audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a man speaking in an informative tone. He references a video he made about the Glazer's strategy at Manchester United, directing the listener to watch it. He explains that the Glazer's strategy at Manchester United revolves around achieving a top four finish rather than winning trophies, which he states is a change since the Glazers took over.

The audio clip begins with a passionate male speaker stating his intention to prove that "the Glazers are thieves at Manchester United", referring to a leveraged buyout deal in 2005 and citing research. His tone is assertive, urging listeners to like and share the video, suggesting a call to action, followed by a sentiment that he is not going to "sit by and ignore as it happens." The speaker intends to talk about it and show "the true scale of the thievery" that has occurred since the Glazers took ownership in 2005.

The audio begins with a male speaker expressing his opinion that the success of Manchester United was "in spite of the Glazers," rather than because of them. He mentions an analysis by "Swiss Ramble" about football and business. He speaks in a casual, conversational tone, and then acknowledges that his analysis may not be enjoyable for fans but emphasizes its importance for understanding.

The audio clip starts with someone counting to five, followed by a male speaker who states that his video is using an analysis that covers the last five years. He continues, explaining that it is about what happened with 20 Premier League clubs. The speaker suggests they will look at all twenty at once to start, focusing on the financing.

A male speaker with a factual tone states investment figures for several soccer teams, noting that one team had money removed from it. The tone is critical, especially when mentioning that team's owners.

The audio clip features one male speaker with an angry tone. He asserts the club is being used as a "cash cow", dismissing the investment made on signings and claims that the Glazers are taking money out of the club, investing only in "the Glazers' pockets."

The clip starts with one male speaker referring to a list and lamenting the position of the football club "United". He criticizes the club's financial state and accuses the owners of taking money out of the club through dividends, claiming "we are the only club to pay dividends to their owners" and that they've paid more to the owners than they paid for players. He questions whether they are thieves. He continues, suggesting that the owners are not using United to win the Premier League again. His tone is critical and frustrated.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing economics, stating that "it's not just with the dividends that money is leaving the United," adding it's leaving "at a rapid rate." He then instructs the listener to "have a look at this in terms of the external financing." The speaker uses a conversational tone.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing Manchester United's financial losses, mentioning "80 million pounds," "the Glazers bought United," and "interest repayments," suggesting frustration in his tone. He continues by comparing these figures to those of Arsenal and Tottenham Hotspur, stressing that, unlike them, United is paying for the Glazers' purchase loan, labeling the situation as unfair and saying, "it's fucked." The speaker's tone conveys disappointment and anger, underscoring the financial implications of the club's ownership.

A male speaker expresses frustration regarding financial gains made by banks and the Glazers, mentioning "hundreds and hundreds of millions" in interest repayments and dividends. He suggests the Glazers will make further significant profits when they sell Manchester United. The speaker's tone conveys anger and disapproval, emphasizing the substantial financial benefits these entities have gained.

The clip starts with a single male speaker expressing his frustration, his tone passionate and angry. He criticizes Manchester United's current state, calling it "a business first" and a "cash cow". He compares their financial situation unfavorably to other clubs like Man City and Liverpool, citing specific figures and highlighting the substantial amounts spent under the Glazers' ownership. The speaker's tone intensifies as he concludes, stating "Fuck the Glazers".

The clip begins with a single male speaker discussing Alex Ferguson's success with Manchester United, specifically referring to a team between 2006 and 2009 as arguably the best Premier League team ever. He states that their accomplishments happened "in spite of the Glazers" and that Ferguson "managed to do that and managed to rebuild a title-winning team." The overall tone is informative and analytical.

A man speaks in an impassioned tone about underinvestment, not signing players, and the lack of support for the manager, mentioning "the scale of the thievery," interest repayments, and nearly a billion leaving. The speaker has an English accent.

A man speaks with an exasperated tone, saying that it "pisses me off" that people would say, "oh, you signed Harry Maguire, oh, you signed Aaron Wan-Bissaka," when they don't understand the scale of the "theivery" at United under the Glazers, because these numbers are "insignificant" compared to the "significant theivery", "constant dividends", "interest repayments" and "leverage buyout". He concludes with frustration that there is nothing more he can say or do about it, but it's important not to ignore it.

The clip starts with a male speaker addressing "a set of fans" and encouraging them to do whatever they can, referencing hashtags and trending topics. He emphasizes his contribution through videos that present evidence about the Glazer's ownership of Manchester United, their strategy, and their financial impact on the club, contrasting this with investments made by other clubs. The speaker expresses the feeling that United is "not a football club anymore", and instead a "business first."

The audio clip begins with a man speaking, quoting something about the cost of lies, then summarizing the financial costs, including interest repayments and dividends. His tone is somewhat frustrated and urgent, ending with "fuck the Glazers, man" and an appeal to share the message about the dire situation at Manchester United. The clip concludes with a sound.
